values.description:
When I originally made the `AttachMeshShape(~)` API, I thought the SDF scale information would be placed into `ignition::common::Mesh` using the `Mesh::Scale(~)` function, but I now realize that the "scale" referred to in the `common::Mesh` API is extracted from the original mesh file. It's not something that can account for the user-defined `<scale>` element of SDF.

This PR allows users \(or `ign-gazebo`\) to pass along scaling information to the physics engine.
values.title: Allow the AttachMeshShape(~) function to accept a scale argument

summary.raw:
When I originally made the `AttachMeshShape(~)` API, I thought the SDF scale information would be placed into `ignition::common::Mesh` using the `Mesh::Scale(~)` function, but I now realize that the "scale" referred to in the `common::Mesh` API is extracted from the original mesh file. It's not something that can account for the user-defined `<scale>` element of SDF.

This PR allows users \(or `ign-gazebo`\) to pass along scaling information to the physics engine.
summary.html:
When I originally made the AttachMeshShape(~) API, I thought the SDF scale information would be placed into ignition::common::Mesh using the Mesh::Scale(~) function, but I now realize that the "scale" referred to in the common::Mesh API is extracted from the original mesh file. It's not something that can account for the user-defined <scale> element of SDF.

This PR allows users (or ign-gazebo) to pass along scaling information to the physics engine.

values.description:
There is an issue with the dart cmake config files that causes downstream projects to have trouble linking to console_bridge on macOS mojave, because it no longer looks in `/usr/local/lib` for libraries by default:

* https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/1200

This is a workaround until the following fix is released:

* https://github.com/dartsim/dart/pull/1209
values.title: Hack for macOS mojave to link to -lconsole_bridge

summary.raw:
There is an issue with the dart cmake config files that causes downstream projects to have trouble linking to console_bridge on macOS mojave, because it no longer looks in `/usr/local/lib` for libraries by default:

* https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/1200

This is a workaround until the following fix is released:

* https://github.com/dartsim/dart/pull/1209
summary.html:
There is an issue with the dart cmake config files that causes downstream projects to have trouble linking to console_bridge on macOS mojave, because it no longer looks in /usr/local/lib for libraries by default:

  • https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/1200

This is a workaround until the following fix is released:

values.title: Use references in an Entity

summary.html:
This pull request lays the foundation for the upcoming remove entities feature. The idea is if an engine supports reference-counted entities, we should use those references to manipulate the entities inside the engine. This would prevent segfaults or exceptions from occurring when operations are performed on a removed entity via an EntityPtr object.

This is different from what we are doing right now in the dartsim wrapper because we store strong references in EntityStorage data structures and use those to manipulate the entities in the engine.

eg.

Instead of

 const std::string &EntityManagementFeatures::GetModelName(
     const std::size_t _modelID) const
 {
   return this->models.at(_modelID)->getName();
 }

we would have 

  const std::string &EntityManagementFeatures::GetModelName(
     const Identity &_modelID) const
 {
   return this->ReferenceInterface<DartSkeleton>(_modelID)->getName();
 }

In the first GetModelName, the call to this->models.at(_modelID) will throw if the model has been removed. But in the second GetModelName, getName is called via the pointer stored in the EntityPtr (actually in the Identity object of Entity). This call would succeed even if the model is removed from the world because the the memory allocated for the skeleton would not have been destroyed.

TODO:

  • ReferenceInterface is currently used only in a couple of places for proof of concept. If the concept is acceptable, I'll update the rest of the implementation.

values.description:
The latest DART release is needed to fix mesh contact points as described [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/125/do-not-merge-pass-the-information-from-sdf/diff#comment-88655365).

Since some of us are using DART packages from OSRF and this will require DART's ppa, bumping the minimum version should alert people that there's something wrong with their setup.
values.title: Bump DART required version to fix mesh contacts

summary.raw:
The latest DART release is needed to fix mesh contact points as described [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/125/do-not-merge-pass-the-information-from-sdf/diff#comment-88655365).

Since some of us are using DART packages from OSRF and this will require DART's ppa, bumping the minimum version should alert people that there's something wrong with their setup.
summary.html:
The latest DART release is needed to fix mesh contact points as described here.

Since some of us are using DART packages from OSRF and this will require DART's ppa, bumping the minimum version should alert people that there's something wrong with their setup.

values.description:
This should fix both collision issues reported [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/issues/8) by simply switching to the ODE collision detection engine instead of using the Bullet collision detection engine. Plane-Mesh collisions and Mesh-Mesh collisions both seem to be failing when using the Bullet collision detector, but those collision type pairs both seem to work just fine using ODE.

~~I haven't been able to verify this using~~ `ign-gazebo` because of [the issue that I reported here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/issues/12), but I wrote [a pure-DART test application available here](https://github.com/mxgrey/sandbox/blob/master/dart/mesh.cpp) which can verify that mesh-mesh collisions fail when using the Bullet collision detector but succeed when using the ODE collision detector.

Note that this changes which components of `dartsim` that `ign-physics` depends on from `collision-bullet` to `collision-ode`, so I think we’ll need to change [this line](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics-release/src/404d9359f6b01b0a73e8a8088225dd10c2460b35/ubuntu/debian/control#lines-41) \(Edit: I’ve opened a [PR for that](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics-release/pull-requests/3)\). @_jrivero_ : Are there other places where this dependency information needs to be updated?
values.title: Use ODE for collision detection instead of Bullet

summary.raw:
This should fix both collision issues reported [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/issues/8) by simply switching to the ODE collision detection engine instead of using the Bullet collision detection engine. Plane-Mesh collisions and Mesh-Mesh collisions both seem to be failing when using the Bullet collision detector, but those collision type pairs both seem to work just fine using ODE.

~~I haven't been able to verify this using~~ `ign-gazebo` because of [the issue that I reported here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/issues/12), but I wrote [a pure-DART test application available here](https://github.com/mxgrey/sandbox/blob/master/dart/mesh.cpp) which can verify that mesh-mesh collisions fail when using the Bullet collision detector but succeed when using the ODE collision detector.

Note that this changes which components of `dartsim` that `ign-physics` depends on from `collision-bullet` to `collision-ode`, so I think we’ll need to change [this line](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics-release/src/404d9359f6b01b0a73e8a8088225dd10c2460b35/ubuntu/debian/control#lines-41) \(Edit: I’ve opened a [PR for that](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics-release/pull-requests/3)\). @_jrivero_ : Are there other places where this dependency information needs to be updated?
summary.html:
This should fix both collision issues reported here by simply switching to the ODE collision detection engine instead of using the Bullet collision detection engine. Plane-Mesh collisions and Mesh-Mesh collisions both seem to be failing when using the Bullet collision detector, but those collision type pairs both seem to work just fine using ODE.

I haven't been able to verify this using ign-gazebo because of the issue that I reported here, but I wrote a pure-DART test application available here which can verify that mesh-mesh collisions fail when using the Bullet collision detector but succeed when using the ODE collision detector.

Note that this changes which components of dartsim that ign-physics depends on from collision-bullet to collision-ode, so I think we’ll need to change this line (Edit: I’ve opened a PR for that). @jrivero : Are there other places where this dependency information needs to be updated?

values.description:
This is a follow-up to pull request #65. Besides switching to the ODE collision detector, it also adds features for attaching plane shapes, and introduces a unit test to verify that plane-mesh collisions are being detected.

I split this out into a separate PR from pull request #65 so that the other one can be treated as a hot fix to get meshes and planes all working properly while this PR can be reviewed more thoroughly.
values.title: Add PlaneShape features + test

summary.raw:
This is a follow-up to pull request #65. Besides switching to the ODE collision detector, it also adds features for attaching plane shapes, and introduces a unit test to verify that plane-mesh collisions are being detected.

I split this out into a separate PR from pull request #65 so that the other one can be treated as a hot fix to get meshes and planes all working properly while this PR can be reviewed more thoroughly.
summary.html:
This is a follow-up to pull request #65. Besides switching to the ODE collision detector, it also adds features for attaching plane shapes, and introduces a unit test to verify that plane-mesh collisions are being detected.

I split this out into a separate PR from pull request #65 so that the other one can be treated as a hot fix to get meshes and planes all working properly while this PR can be reviewed more thoroughly.

values.description:
This pull request adds a feature that retrieves the list of contacts generated in the previous simulation step. Currently, only the two colliding entities and the point of contact are included in the data that's retrieved.

Note: I had to change the `Key2` type for many of the `EntityStorage` objects to consts in order to be able to lookup entities with const pointers.
values.title: [Acropolis] GetContactsFromLastStep feature

summary.raw:
This pull request adds a feature that retrieves the list of contacts generated in the previous simulation step. Currently, only the two colliding entities and the point of contact are included in the data that's retrieved.

summary.html:
This pull request adds a feature that retrieves the list of contacts generated in the previous simulation step. Currently, only the two colliding entities and the point of contact are included in the data that's retrieved.

Note: I had to change the Key2 type for many of the EntityStorage objects to consts in order to be able to lookup entities with const pointers.

values.description:
There are various functions for adding forces in osrf/Gazebo. The differences among the functions arise from the frame of references used to express the force and the offset position. I have tried to consolidate the APIs by creating two functions, one that offers the most flexibility by accepting `RelativeQuantity` parameters, and another that uses `LinearVector` parameters and a reference frame with the assumption that the position is always expressed in the **link-fixed** frame. 

The same is true for adding torques except that it doesn't have the position parameter.
values.title: Feature for adding external forces and torques to a link

summary.raw:
There are various functions for adding forces in osrf/Gazebo. The differences among the functions arise from the frame of references used to express the force and the offset position. I have tried to consolidate the APIs by creating two functions, one that offers the most flexibility by accepting `RelativeQuantity` parameters, and another that uses `LinearVector` parameters and a reference frame with the assumption that the position is always expressed in the **link-fixed** frame. 

The same is true for adding torques except that it doesn't have the position parameter.
summary.html:
There are various functions for adding forces in osrf/Gazebo. The differences among the functions arise from the frame of references used to express the force and the offset position. I have tried to consolidate the APIs by creating two functions, one that offers the most flexibility by accepting RelativeQuantity parameters, and another that uses LinearVector parameters and a reference frame with the assumption that the position is always expressed in the link-fixed frame.

The same is true for adding torques except that it doesn't have the position parameter.

values.description:
This is a small PR to assign friction coefficients from the `<surface>` tags of `<collision>` elements. There are a couple of issues to keep in mind.

* We are using the coefficient specified in the <ode> tag.  I left a TODO to either add SDF parameters specific to DART or generic to all physics engines.
* Shape nodes can have friction coefficients in DART but they don't have any effect in simulation. Instead, the friction coefficient of body nodes are used in the [constraint solver](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/blob/master/dart/constraint/ContactConstraint.cpp#L107-L108). So, in this PR, we are setting the friction coefficient of a collision element to be the coefficient for the whole link. And if there are multiple collision elements, the value of the last one will be the coefficient for the link.
values.title: [Acropolis] Assign friction coefficients from collision elements

summary.raw:
This is a small PR to assign friction coefficients from the `<surface>` tags of `<collision>` elements. There are a couple of issues to keep in mind.

* We are using the coefficient specified in the <ode> tag.  I left a TODO to either add SDF parameters specific to DART or generic to all physics engines.
* Shape nodes can have friction coefficients in DART but they don't have any effect in simulation. Instead, the friction coefficient of body nodes are used in the [constraint solver](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/blob/master/dart/constraint/ContactConstraint.cpp#L107-L108). So, in this PR, we are setting the friction coefficient of a collision element to be the coefficient for the whole link. And if there are multiple collision elements, the value of the last one will be the coefficient for the link.
summary.html:
This is a small PR to assign friction coefficients from the <surface> tags of <collision> elements. There are a couple of issues to keep in mind.

  • We are using the coefficient specified in the <ode> tag. I left a TODO to either add SDF parameters specific to DART or generic to all physics engines.
  • Shape nodes can have friction coefficients in DART but they don't have any effect in simulation. Instead, the friction coefficient of body nodes are used in the constraint solver. So, in this PR, we are setting the friction coefficient of a collision element to be the coefficient for the whole link. And if there are multiple collision elements, the value of the last one will be the coefficient for the link.

values.description:
This PR drastically improves the compile times of applications and libraries that use `ign-physics`. The key issue was that the length of symbol names was growing unbounded for classes that were being instantiated from templates. The itanium ABI mangles the names of template arguments into the symbol names of classes that get instantiated from templates, so the full name of each new feature that we added to a link, model, joint, world, etc, was getting mangled into all the symbol names that were being produced.

This PR mitigates this by using some class inheritance and SNFINAE tricks that allow us to easily minimize the symbol names. For example, a symbol that used to come out as

```
_ZTIN8ignition7physics6detail9AggregateINS1_12SelectEngineEvvE4typeIJNS0_13FeaturePolicyIdLm3EEENS0_11FeatureListIJNS8_IJNS0_26GetCylinderShapePropertiesENS0_26SetCylinderShapePropertiesENS0_26AttachCylinderShapeFeatureEEEENS8_IJNS0_26GetRevoluteJointPropertiesENS0_26SetRevoluteJointPropertiesEEEENS8_IJNS0_21GetBoxShapePropertiesENS0_21SetBoxShapePropertiesENS0_21AttachBoxShapeFeatureEEEEEEEEEE
```

can now come out as

```
_ZTIN8ignition7physics6detail9AggregateINS1_12SelectEngineENS1_7GetNextINS4_I15FeatureSetClassvE1nEvE1nEvE4typeIJNS0_13FeaturePolicyIdLm3EEES5_EEE
```

We can also add many more features into this symbol without significantly impacting the length of its name. The key is to group features into sets of features using explicit inheritance. For example, we use to do this:

```
using MyFeatureList = ignition::physics::FeatureList<
  /* some list of features */
>;
```

but now we can do this instead:

```
struct MyFeatureList : ignition::physics::FeatureList<
  /* some list of features */
> { };
```

and the resulting symbol names from using `MyFeatureList` will be very lean and not have any dependence on the lengths of the feature names.

This matters primarily because the compile times on GCC seem to grow almost exponentially as the sizes of symbol names increase. Clang is also affected, but not as severely. Here are some charts of the compile times that I observed before and after these changes:

| Before | -j1 | -j16 |
| --- | --- | --- |
| gcc | 17:59 | 15:18 |
| clang | 5:30 | 1:55 |

| After | -j1 | -j16 |
| --- | --- | --- |
| gcc | 6:58 | 2:05 |
| clang | 5:11 | 1:12 |

This PR depends on an [ign-plugin PR here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-plugin/pull-requests/32/).

Update: retargeted to `improve_compile_times_headers` branch of pr #93
values.title: [Citadel] Improve compile times

summary.raw:
This PR drastically improves the compile times of applications and libraries that use `ign-physics`. The key issue was that the length of symbol names was growing unbounded for classes that were being instantiated from templates. The itanium ABI mangles the names of template arguments into the symbol names of classes that get instantiated from templates, so the full name of each new feature that we added to a link, model, joint, world, etc, was getting mangled into all the symbol names that were being produced.

This PR mitigates this by using some class inheritance and SNFINAE tricks that allow us to easily minimize the symbol names. For example, a symbol that used to come out as

```
_ZTIN8ignition7physics6detail9AggregateINS1_12SelectEngineEvvE4typeIJNS0_13FeaturePolicyIdLm3EEENS0_11FeatureListIJNS8_IJNS0_26GetCylinderShapePropertiesENS0_26SetCylinderShapePropertiesENS0_26AttachCylinderShapeFeatureEEEENS8_IJNS0_26GetRevoluteJointPropertiesENS0_26SetRevoluteJointPropertiesEEEENS8_IJNS0_21GetBoxShapePropertiesENS0_21SetBoxShapePropertiesENS0_21AttachBoxShapeFeatureEEEEEEEEEE
```

can now come out as

```
_ZTIN8ignition7physics6detail9AggregateINS1_12SelectEngineENS1_7GetNextINS4_I15FeatureSetClassvE1nEvE1nEvE4typeIJNS0_13FeaturePolicyIdLm3EEES5_EEE
```

We can also add many more features into this symbol without significantly impacting the length of its name. The key is to group features into sets of features using explicit inheritance. For example, we use to do this:

```
using MyFeatureList = ignition::physics::FeatureList<
  /* some list of features */
>;
```

but now we can do this instead:

```
struct MyFeatureList : ignition::physics::FeatureList<
  /* some list of features */
> { };
```

and the resulting symbol names from using `MyFeatureList` will be very lean and not have any dependence on the lengths of the feature names.

This matters primarily because the compile times on GCC seem to grow almost exponentially as the sizes of symbol names increase. Clang is also affected, but not as severely. Here are some charts of the compile times that I observed before and after these changes:

| Before | -j1 | -j16 |
| --- | --- | --- |
| gcc | 17:59 | 15:18 |
| clang | 5:30 | 1:55 |

| After | -j1 | -j16 |
| --- | --- | --- |
| gcc | 6:58 | 2:05 |
| clang | 5:11 | 1:12 |

This PR depends on an [ign-plugin PR here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-plugin/pull-requests/32/).

Update: retargeted to `improve_compile_times_headers` branch of pr #93
summary.html:
This PR drastically improves the compile times of applications and libraries that use ign-physics. The key issue was that the length of symbol names was growing unbounded for classes that were being instantiated from templates. The itanium ABI mangles the names of template arguments into the symbol names of classes that get instantiated from templates, so the full name of each new feature that we added to a link, model, joint, world, etc, was getting mangled into all the symbol names that were being produced.

This PR mitigates this by using some class inheritance and SNFINAE tricks that allow us to easily minimize the symbol names. For example, a symbol that used to come out as

_ZTIN8ignition7physics6detail9AggregateINS1_12SelectEngineEvvE4typeIJNS0_13FeaturePolicyIdLm3EEENS0_11FeatureListIJNS8_IJNS0_26GetCylinderShapePropertiesENS0_26SetCylinderShapePropertiesENS0_26AttachCylinderShapeFeatureEEEENS8_IJNS0_26GetRevoluteJointPropertiesENS0_26SetRevoluteJointPropertiesEEEENS8_IJNS0_21GetBoxShapePropertiesENS0_21SetBoxShapePropertiesENS0_21AttachBoxShapeFeatureEEEEEEEEEE

can now come out as

_ZTIN8ignition7physics6detail9AggregateINS1_12SelectEngineENS1_7GetNextINS4_I15FeatureSetClassvE1nEvE1nEvE4typeIJNS0_13FeaturePolicyIdLm3EEES5_EEE

We can also add many more features into this symbol without significantly impacting the length of its name. The key is to group features into sets of features using explicit inheritance. For example, we use to do this:

using MyFeatureList = ignition::physics::FeatureList<
  /* some list of features */
>;

but now we can do this instead:

struct MyFeatureList : ignition::physics::FeatureList<
  /* some list of features */
> { };

and the resulting symbol names from using MyFeatureList will be very lean and not have any dependence on the lengths of the feature names.

This matters primarily because the compile times on GCC seem to grow almost exponentially as the sizes of symbol names increase. Clang is also affected, but not as severely. Here are some charts of the compile times that I observed before and after these changes:

Before -j1 -j16
gcc 17:59 15:18
clang 5:30 1:55
After -j1 -j16
gcc 6:58 2:05
clang 5:11 1:12

This PR depends on an ign-plugin PR here.

Update: retargeted to improve_compile_times_headers branch of pr #93

values.description:
Motivated by: \(suggested by @{557058:90bc87b0-2886-4377-a17c-3a6629a697ff} \)

I’ve uploaded the latest 6.9.0 dart packages to our prerelease repo. The testing jobs seems fine to me:

![](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_physics-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64&build=309)
[https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition\_physics-ci-pr\_any-ubuntu\_auto-amd64/309/](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_physics-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/309/))

@{557058:5de38267-b118-494c-aa76-4fab35448816} has [submitted a PR](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/pull/40422) to update Dart in homebrew. We are not using DART on Windows right now.

values.description: Currently gtest and the test plugins are compiled even if `-DBUILD_TESTING=OFF` is passed to cmake. This fixes that, which should speed up compilation when that variable is set.
values.title: Skip compilation of test plugins if `BUILD_TESTING` is false

summary.raw: Currently gtest and the test plugins are compiled even if `-DBUILD_TESTING=OFF` is passed to cmake. This fixes that, which should speed up compilation when that variable is set.
summary.html: Currently gtest and the test plugins are compiled even if -DBUILD_TESTING=OFF is passed to cmake. This fixes that, which should speed up compilation when that variable is set.

values.description:
This pulls out the changes to header files from pull request #88 and targets to `ign-physics1` to confirm that API and ABI are not affected by these changes. It requires [ign-plugin pr 32](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-plugin/pull-requests/32), which is also the ign-plugin 1.1.0~pre1 prerelease.

When testing with [release-tools branch physics_prerelease](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/branch/physics_prerelease), the ubuntu and API/ABI build are happy:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_physics-abichecker-any_to_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64&build=98)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_physics-abichecker-any_to_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/98/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_physics-abichecker-any_to_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/98/
* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_physics-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64&build=328)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_physics-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/328/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_physics-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/328/

I expect that this branch won't have the speed-up; this is just for reviewing API/ABI compatibility. I'll make a subsequent PR targeted to this branch that should demonstrate the speedup.
values.title: [Citadel] Improve compile time: headers only

summary.raw:
This pulls out the changes to header files from pull request #88 and targets to `ign-physics1` to confirm that API and ABI are not affected by these changes. It requires [ign-plugin pr 32](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-plugin/pull-requests/32), which is also the ign-plugin 1.1.0~pre1 prerelease.

When testing with [release-tools branch physics_prerelease](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/branch/physics_prerelease), the ubuntu and API/ABI build are happy:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_physics-abichecker-any_to_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64&build=98)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_physics-abichecker-any_to_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/98/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_physics-abichecker-any_to_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/98/
* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_physics-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64&build=328)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_physics-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/328/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_physics-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/328/

I expect that this branch won't have the speed-up; this is just for reviewing API/ABI compatibility. I'll make a subsequent PR targeted to this branch that should demonstrate the speedup.
summary.html:
This pulls out the changes to header files from pull request #88 and targets to ign-physics1 to confirm that API and ABI are not affected by these changes. It requires ign-plugin pr 32, which is also the ign-plugin 1.1.0~pre1 prerelease.

When testing with release-tools branch physics_prerelease, the ubuntu and API/ABI build are happy:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_physics-abichecker-any_to_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/98/
  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_physics-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/328/

I expect that this branch won't have the speed-up; this is just for reviewing API/ABI compatibility. I'll make a subsequent PR targeted to this branch that should demonstrate the speedup.

values.description:
Sets friction pyramid parameters on ShapeNode DynamicsAspect instead of BodyNode. This needs a new release of DART using the `azeey/friction_per_shape_more_params` branch of https://github.com/azeey/dart. This is mainly @{557058:5de38267-b118-494c-aa76-4fab35448816}'s work but hosted on my repo in order to fix handling of the first frictional direction. With this PR, the following parameters from `<friction><ode>` are now supported:

* `<mu2>`
* `<fdir1>`
* `<slip1>`
* `<slip2>`
values.title: Support more friction pyramid parameters

summary.raw:
Sets friction pyramid parameters on ShapeNode DynamicsAspect instead of BodyNode. This needs a new release of DART using the `azeey/friction_per_shape_more_params` branch of https://github.com/azeey/dart. This is mainly @{557058:5de38267-b118-494c-aa76-4fab35448816}'s work but hosted on my repo in order to fix handling of the first frictional direction. With this PR, the following parameters from `<friction><ode>` are now supported:

summary.html:
Sets friction pyramid parameters on ShapeNode DynamicsAspect instead of BodyNode. This needs a new release of DART using the azeey/friction_per_shape_more_params branch of https://github.com/azeey/dart. This is mainly @Steve Peters's work but hosted on my repo in order to fix handling of the first frictional direction. With this PR, the following parameters from <friction><ode> are now supported:

  • <mu2>
  • <fdir1>
  • <slip1>
  • <slip2>

values.description:
Implement Bullet plugin for physics simulation.

Requires [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/403](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/403).

It breaks API/ABI, so it is targeted at `default`.

Current features support running `shapes.sdf` and `world_joint.sdf`.

‌

Note:

1\. Current implementation is not optimized for efficiency yet.

2\. Tests not yet added.
values.title: [WIP] Add Bullet physics engine

values.description:
Implement Bullet plugin for physics simulation.

Requires [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/403](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/403).

Current features support running:

* `shapes.sdf`
* `world_joint.sdf`
* `diff_drive.sdf`
* `apply_joint_force.sdf`
* `quadcopter.sdf`

Some previous discussion in [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/97](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/97).

‌

Note:

1\. Current implementation is not optimized for efficiency yet.

2\. Tests not complete.

3\. Behavior for car\_collision.sdf example might be different between Bullet 2.87 and 2.88.
values.title: [WIP] Add Bullet physics engine

summary.html:
Implement Bullet plugin for physics simulation.

Requires #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/403.

Current features support running:

  • shapes.sdf
  • world_joint.sdf
  • diff_drive.sdf
  • apply_joint_force.sdf
  • quadcopter.sdf

Some previous discussion in #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/97.

‌

Note:

1. Current implementation is not optimized for efficiency yet.

2. Tests not complete.

3. Behavior for car_collision.sdf example might be different between Bullet 2.87 and 2.88.
